[9](#footnote-anchor-9) Sources: Facebook, Instagram, and YouTube stats [here](https://www.forbes.com/sites/marisadellatto/2022/03/24/spotify-says-it-paid-7-billion-in-royalties-in-2021-amid-claims-of-low-pay-from-artists/); in 2021 Spotify paid [$7bn](https://www.forbes.com/sites/marisadellatto/2022/03/24/spotify-says-it-paid-7-billion-in-royalties-in-2021-amid-claims-of-low-pay-from-artists/) to [8 million](https://www.forbes.com/sites/marisadellatto/2022/03/24/spotify-says-it-paid-7-billion-in-royalties-in-2021-amid-claims-of-low-pay-from-artists/) creators, which is $875 or Â£700 (slightly higher than the claim in the a16z source above).

[10](#footnote-anchor-10) Take the price of Bitcoin as a proxy for â€˜web3 in vogueâ€™ for a moment. When a16z published the 100 True Fans articles in February 2020, Bitcoin was worth under <$10k, and wouldnâ€™t get above that price until October. The niche market vibe shift predates the cultural significance of web3 and crypto.

[11](#footnote-anchor-11) Iâ€™m simplifying a lot; this isnâ€™t a technical introduction to web3. Most obviously, itâ€™s not the case that each person has to manually agree everything in a distributed ledger. Rather, itâ€™s every computer server; and itâ€™s not every computer server, itâ€™s those who proactively commit to contributing to manage the ledger and communicating with it. A good introductory podcast [here](https://open.spotify.com/episode/6N7cIUkh0DnADrJpWlzcY3?si=7rj7ns-AQTqwShJvTHRfOQ); a more detailed introduction [here](https://ethereum.org/en/web3/); a more technical and key whitepaper [here](https://ethereum.org/en/whitepaper/); and for more depth I suggest the further reading listed under the whitepaper.

[12](#footnote-anchor-12) This illustrates Vitalik Buterinâ€™s (founder of Ethereum) infamous Uber [quote](https://proxet.com/blog/how-the-blockchain-is-changing-money-and-business/#:\~:text=%E2%80%9C-,whereas%20,-most%20%20tend%20%20workers): taxi profiles will be stored on chain, and Uber, Lyft, and more will compete to show you the same drivers, giving the drivers much more power and compensation â€” which they [need](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Power_resource_theory). *(There we go, I actually got a politics link in.)*

[13](#footnote-anchor-13) This idea comes from Alexis Ohanian, co-founder of Reddit. I donâ€™t think MVC will *replace* MVP - you still need a good product - but your community has to be part of the same conversation.

title: Problem Solving & Storytelling
body:
Some thoughts on why we're so polarized and incapable of constructive dialogue...

Human experience comes down to two things: problem solving and storytelling.

Problem solving is the cybernetic process of communication and control in the pursuit of goals.

Storytelling is the sense-making of our experience as problem solvers through goal-directed behavior.

Cybernetics is the idea that in the pursuit of some goal (docking a boat) we have to constantly adapt to our environment (wind, rain, tide) and adjust course (steer) to achieve that goal.

What we take in and how we react to it is a circular feedback process, and we judge our success by how close or far away we are from our goal. This process operates at every level of life â€” the goals just shift based on local context and conditions.

At the human level, each of us pursue our own goals and sense-make for ourselves. We individually construct an interpretation of our experience according to our own central nervous system and consciousness.

Itâ€™s only in relation to other human beings that we have to contend with the goals of other individuals. And itâ€™s there where shared or competing goals are determined.

Socially, weâ€™re aided by shared languaging (the totality of our intercommunications) and the emergent culture surrounding us, which further scaffolds, frames, and constrains our individual experience of sense-making.

Our personal realities are relative, subject to the localized information available to oneâ€™s consciousness in each moment. But through languaging and conversation, we explore our intersubjective experiences of the world together.

Conversation is used to explore potential solutions to perceived problems. If an intersubjective, shared meaning can be established, a foundation for collaborative sense-making and storytelling can be built upon. Agreement might be found.

However, if the â€œmaps of meaningâ€ arenâ€™t agreed upon, the definition of the â€œproblemâ€, defined as oneâ€™s distance from the imagined goal, also canâ€™t be agreed upon and collaborative progress wonâ€™t be made.

The conversation will be deemed unproductive and impractical relative to oneâ€™s goal and violence will be inevitable.

When each partyâ€™s perspective is based on the belief that â€œfactsâ€ exist, independent of observers, it leads to entrenched positions. Reason no longer works.

New â€œfactsâ€ aren't accepted because the framing of those facts is entangled in the subjective scaffolding of the individual and the emergent cultural context theyâ€™re embedded within.

The other observer is embedded in a different â€œreality.â€ The information of their intersubjective experience is only accessible to them and like-minded others.

Good faith conversation between parties with opposing viewpoints remains our only hope for resolution, but no shared agreement should be expected.

The distance between consciousnesses and their sense-making, the perceived problems to be solved, and the culture that enmeshes these experiences, is too great.

But we have to keep trying.

title: Community and the niche market vibe shift
body:
***Brands and creators that build for niche and dedicated communities will win the 2020s.***

Iâ€™ve seen a lot more sweetshops around recently. Specifically, these Victorian-themed tuckshops and sweet connoisseurs, plucked from two hundred years prior and plopped in the middle of a high street that doesnâ€™t quite know how to welcome its new tenant. One of the sweet shops near me plasters â€˜Toys, Trains, Treatsâ€ on dated storefront panelling; itâ€™s the shop you thought your grandparents went to when they were young, except the steam trains on sale are battery powered.

This wasnâ€™t just a Baaderâ€“Meinhof [phenomenon](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Frequency_illusion), where upon seeing something once you perceive it everywhere. During the first year of the pandemic, an extra [73](https://www.mylondon.news/news/uk-world-news/i-visited-londons-new-dangerous-22961908#:\~:text=73%20more%20sweet%20shops%20in%20the%20uk%20compared%20with%202020) sweetshops popped up in the UK, net, according to the Local Data Company. Thatâ€™s not a huge number, but itâ€™s pretty significant given the broader lockdown context; the total number of clothing shops fell by 1,236 in the same period[1](#footnote-1). The shop near me was set up in September â€˜21. It begs the question: whatâ€™s so special about sweet shops?

I had spent my Saturday morning at Waterstones buying some books, at the sweet shop questioning the shop assistant, and now Iâ€™m writing about it on Substack. In days gone by, I would have bought my physical items at Sainsburyâ€™s and, in comparison to today, where I have my Substack and my main [website](https://www.leonasskau.co.uk/), all my digital publishing would be through the same technology stack, probably Wordpress.

Sweets are nice, but the real difference is the existence of a shop that will focus all of its resources on their specific niche product. I bought some weird caramel chocolate flakes that defy description, but they were excellent. I certainly paid a premium, but next time I want sweets, Iâ€™ll go there again, because *they know their product*; I just bought what the shop assistant recommended. At Waterstoneâ€™s, I picked up [Train Dreams](https://www.theguardian.com/books/2012/sep/13/train-dreams-denis-johnson-review) because I told the manager I was after contemporary fiction; I use Substack because itâ€™s built for writers[2](#footnote-2). **What makes these businesses special is that they serve *niche markets in which they can give people much deeper value.***

![I mean, you get what Iâ€™m saying, despite the weird animojis, right? (HelloDorking)](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/xRINH9-26W7ZvCggFpXtm.jpeg?height=2438&width=3024)

## Unbundling into niches

Bundling and unbundling are [not new concepts](https://hbr.org/1999/03/unbundling-the-corporation). Itâ€™s a pretty simple convection model: you start with a business, over time you add more products, services, and features, and then you get bloated, do everything â€˜kinda wellâ€™, until a niche competitor comes along and does *one* of your services *really really well*, and bit by bit you get pieced apart. The [complexity convection](https://every.to/divinations/complexity-convection-765851) is a pattern that cannot be unseen. 

People have observed this happening to our contemporary digital landscape for about a decade, beginning in practice much earlier. Craigslist was [unbundled](https://thegongshow.tumblr.com/post/345941486/the-spawn-of-craigslist-like-most-vcs-that-focus) into many things, including Reddit, which is now being [unbundled](https://latecheckout.substack.com/p/the-guide-to-unbundling-reddit?s=r) into many more things, like Nextdoor. In the language of [a16z](https://a16z.com/2019/09/11/platforms-verticals-unbundling/), the famed tech investors: platforms get unbundled into verticals, which turn into platforms, at which point the cycle resumes, and all of a sudden Iâ€™ve turned into a strategy writer[3](#footnote-3). 

Iâ€™m not the first to herald this unbundling in the physical world either. Peter Day [wrote](https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/magazine-23990211#:\~:text=Economy%2C%20%20almost%20a,speed%20and%20efficiency.) an excellent essay predicting â€œthe heartbeat economy, almost a concierge approach to customers,â€ in 2013:

> `â€œThis would be a worryingly intimate relationship for many businesses, but one which might provide a new kind of rewarding marketplace if they dared to be far closer to their customers' individuality.â€`

He wrote about it in the BBC, but today he would write on his own blog.

My real contribution is to note that this challenges why unbundling and bundling happens at all. The main idea behind why we sway between bundled and unbundled products is the [underlying technology](https://hbr.org/2014/06/how-to-succeed-in-business-by-bundling-and-unbundling#:\~:text=a%20lot%20of%20it%20is%20based%20on%20the%20underlying%20technology%20change). Marc Andreesen, co-founder of a16z and of [Mosaic](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mosaic_(web_browser)), the first web browser, talks through the concept of the newspaper:

> `â€œThe newspaper bundle, the idea of this slug of news and sports scores and classifieds and stock quotes that arrives once a day was a consequence of the printing plant, of the distribution network for newspapers using trucks and newsstands, and the famous newspaper delivery boy. That newspaper bundle was based on the distribution technology of a time and place.`
>
> `When the distribution technology changed with the internet, there was going to be the great unwind, and then the great rebundle, in the form of Google and Facebook and Twitter.â€`

This is certainly true: we could only put [live events on Twitch](https://youtu.be/TCPjk8Tpb5c?t=1025) after network infrastructure made it cheap enough to broadcast live video around the world.

But itâ€™s no coincidence that physical businesses are unbundling at the same time as digital ones, despite relying on different technologies, and often very little tech at all. Neither technology nor innovations built upon it come from magic: what consumers *actually want* plays a key role; today itâ€™s driven by the niche market vibe shift.

Why? Well first, consumer demand fosters technological innovation. I took a cursory glance at solar panels [last month](https://empoweredbelonging.substack.com/p/podcast-discussion-negotiating-our?s=w#:\~:text=we%E2%80%99re%20already%20on%20the%20way.%20solar%2C%20wind%2C%20fusion%2C%20geothermal%2C%20and%20hydrogen%20energy%20technologies%20have%20all%20advanced%20significantly%20even%20in%20the%20past%20decade.), where growing consumer demand and growing production have *induced* new technologies; if people hadnâ€™t bothered to use streaming services in the early days, there wouldnâ€™t have been the investment that made them possible at scale. Substack was built because its founders [believed](https://every.to/divinations/substack-s-ideology) writers wanted to offer readers deeper value in a specific niche - and that [readers would pay for it](https://twitter.com/hamishmckenzie/status/1532432557513404416) â€“ not due to any new technologies, just due to the niche market vibe shift.

Second, even when this technological innovation happens, there is no rule commanding consumers to use every new use case thatâ€™s suddenly made possible. Google, Facebook, and Twitter all had to create new bundles that people actually wanted to use: do [Google+](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Google%2B), [Google Answers](http://answers.google.com/answers/faq.html#:\~:text=google%20answers%20was%20an%20experimental%20product%20for%20users%20to%20get%20help%20from%20researchers%20with%20expertise%20in%20online%20searching.), or [Google Notebook](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Google_Notebook#:\~:text=allowed%20users%20to%20save%20and%20organize%20clips%20of%20information%20while%20conducting%20research%20online) ring a bell?

**I think the reason Iâ€™m seeing more sweetshops around is because of a niche market vibe shift. The technology for serving more niche communities has always existed, but now consumers actually want it. *But what does this mean?***


---

I have two quick points before we move on: why this insight is important and why this shift is happening.

First, understanding that bundling and unbundling cycles sway partly due to social preferences, as well as technology, is important to understanding where these sways stop and start, and how to take advantage of them. If itâ€™s true that people want more meaningful, participatory communities, that tells us a lot more about where the future is going than simply observing the entire possibility space opened up by new technologies. When I looked at those failed Google products, I got the impression that Google - founded by Stanford grads - originally sought to be a lot more academic than it is today, with tools for professional research and note-taking. We can understand that these products failed because they werenâ€™t aligned with the niche market vibe shift of the 21st century, even though they were technically feasible.

Second, my quick take is that this shift has its roots in societyâ€™s search for reciprocal connection. The 21st century is probably the only century that will ever be worth calling â€˜the internet centuryâ€™ (by the 22nd the internet wonâ€™t be exciting anymore). Todayâ€™s internet is very uni-directional, with big influencers megaphoning to their followers[4](#footnote-4). But people also want to [belong ](https://empoweredbelonging.substack.com/about#:\~:text=the%20sense%20of%20belonging%20that%20humans%20inherently%20desire)to something, and as I wrote a few months ago, building connections *[within](https://empoweredbelonging.substack.com/p/leading-movements-communicating-change?s=w#:\~:text=so%20build%20connections-,within,-your%20movement)* your community makes it so much more fulfilling. You feel youâ€™re really participating, and this is really why I go to the sweet shop. Society just invented the internet, and is searching for meaning. Also [G](https://www.theatlantic.com/business/archive/2017/12/great-recession-still-with-us/547268/).[F](https://www.bruegel.org/2018/10/ten-years-after-the-crisis-the-wests-failure-pushing-china-towards-state-capitalism/).[C](https://www.researchgate.net/publication/227439075_THE_IMPACT_OF_THE_ECONOMIC_CRISIS_ON_CULTURE).

![This is a great time to take a break, maybe stretch your legs, and share with a friend! (Kevin Huynh)](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/7pYdkgZ_QQytonD6G7z0-.webp?height=796&width=1456)


---

The rest of this essay is to explore how this shift is influencing culture. We can think pretty big about *all* the unbundling opportunities new technologies bring: in *[Life After Google](https://www.waterstones.com/book/life-after-google/george-gilder/9781621575764)*, Gilder points out that even money *could* be unbundled, though I donâ€™t think this is on the cards. Itâ€™s possible, but consumers donâ€™t actually want to unbundle money into a store of value, unit of account, and so forth. Very few communities are built simply around money as a tool; everyone will *not* become [currency traders](https://foreignpolicy.com/2021/12/11/bitcoin-ethereum-cryptocurrency-web3-great-protocol-politics/#:\~:text=everyone%20becomes%20a%20foreign-exchange%20trader); a niche canâ€™t be built around something that everyone uses, and most people donâ€™t care.

I want to instead focus on culture, which people care a lot about, and is interesting for many further reasons. It interests me how great cultural contributions both capture some image of society whilst also moving it forward[5](#footnote-5). Culture is also beautifully adaptable and flexible and fluid, changing rapidly and exhibiting immense diversity of contribution and consumption: itâ€™s a *collection of niches*. I expect this vibe shift to play out in culture very soon. (It goes without saying that this will occur on the internet.)

That idea of culture as a collection of niches deserves interrogating: culture is also something that we all share. And sure, there will continue to be big Instagram accounts and large supermarkets; shows and books that everyone talks about and events that unite the masses. But as Rex Woodbury notes: â€œ[Celebrities like (Tom) Cruise are a dying breed](https://digitalnative.substack.com/p/cultural-transmission-in-the-internet?token=eyJ1c2VyX2lkIjo1NjA2MzgyNSwicG9zdF9pZCI6NTcwOTkyMTIsIl8iOiJlcTFDOSIsImlhdCI6MTY1NDE2NzYxMywiZXhwIjoxNjU0MTcxMjEzLCJpc3MiOiJwdWItMzg1MDAiLCJzdWIiOiJwb3N0LXJlYWN0aW9uIn0.pfK8o_nxyz7FIehX7-CkXaRKa-d0-3YhcJ1I1r_YRkg&s=r#:\~:text=celebrities%20like%20cruise%20are%20a%20dying%20breed)â€[6](#footnote-6). The 2020s will be defined by the â€œ[long tail of creators](https://digitalnative.substack.com/p/the-two-way-mirror-of-art-and-technology?s=w#:\~:text=embolden%20the%20long%20tail%20of%20creators)â€, each creating en mass for far smaller communities with much deeper engagement. In the 21st century, we will seek experiences that feel, in some important ways (and not all), totally and emphatically human â€” thatâ€™s why people love [eSports](https://erikhoel.substack.com/p/why-watch-other-people-play-video?token=eyJ1c2VyX2lkIjo1NjA2MzgyNSwicG9zdF9pZCI6NDUxMzUyMzksIl8iOiJrK0hyQSIsImlhdCI6MTY1NDIwNjQ5OSwiZXhwIjoxNjU0MjEwMDk5LCJpc3MiOiJwdWItMzMyOTk2Iiwic3ViIjoicG9zdC1yZWFjdGlvbiJ9.T5f6CkyK7SFpzLO3nZZ6U2Zudqkkf4npc9ZsqDnSqFg&s=r#:\~:text=as%20totally%20and%20unabashedly%20human); weâ€™re in the moment *with* the players. **For the hobbies and niches that we love, for which weâ€™re far more than mere followers, weâ€™ll find people serving that niche with dedicated communities built around them.**

[Late Checkout](https://latecheckout.studio/about) is an agency that doesnâ€™t deserve the negative tag associated with such companies[7](#footnote-7); they capture the situation perfectly:

> `â€œThe old way of building products was to try and be everything to everyone. Products were chunky, bloated, and didnâ€™t serve the individual or communities.â€`
>
> `â€œPeople want to feel a connection to the products they use. They want the internet to feel human and alive again.â€`

Itâ€™s exciting to see people building the future, and culturally weâ€™re going to see exactly this: **content will be built around niche and dedicated communities with genuine human connection**[8](#footnote-8).


---

## And thus the 1,000 True Fans thesis eventually manifests.

In 2008, Kevin Kelly wrote one of the most seminal contributions in culture tech. The founding editor-in-chief of Wired wrote that, in the internet age:

> `â€œTo make a living as a craftsperson, photographer, musician, designer, author, animator, app maker, entrepreneur, or inventor you need only thousands of true fans.â€`

A thousand dedicated fans who love your niche. Sound familiar? 

So what took so long?

Itâ€™s certainly the case that the technology of the era made this difficult. Kelly hoped that the internet would be the ultimate matchmaker. Bring the creators and the consumers online, and they will find each other. To an extent, they did, especially in the early days of the internet: in 2008, writing about 1000 True Fans looked sensible. But it was still pretty hard: you could publish your own content, but without mass-market services like Facebook, Instagram, or YouTube, that helped you discover, it was tough to find or be found.

The introduction of these services, monoliths to be, helped in one sense: it was a lot easier for people to find you on the internet. But the price for this matchmaking was almost everything: Facebook and Instagram take almost 100% of all the revenue creators see on their platforms; YouTube takes 45%; Spotify paid an average of merely Â£700 to each artist last year[9](#footnote-9). These monoliths do the matching, but make it virtually unaffordable to create in the first place.

It was a vibe shift, not a technological one, that struck the first blow to this impoverished paradigm. Twitch, Kickstarter, Patreon, Substack, amongst many others, are all services built for creators to cater for the dedicated fans of their niche; all built amidst the community-centric vibe shift born in the 2010s. Well before the 2020 crypto bull run, a16z heralded a [100 True Fans model](https://future.a16z.com/1000-true-fans-try-100/) in 2020[10](#footnote-10), arguing that this was made possible with even more niche services from Podia, Teachable, and Kajabi. (These companies *all* help people sell educational courses, which undermines the argument to an extent, but you only need 250 fans paying Â£20/$25 per month to earn \~3x the average UK salary or [$75,000](https://content.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,2019628,00.html#:\~:text=no%20matter%20how%20much%20more), so you get the picture.) **With the alignment of technology and the vibe, the impoverished paradigm of community-stricken creatorship is collapsing.**


---

### Blockchain is a game-changer for this dynamic

*Youâ€™re reading on Mirror, so you probably know all this; you could easily skip to the next phrase in bold.*

In the early 2020s, new technologies like blockchain, distributed ledgers, and cryptocurrencies really came in vogue. A distributed ledger is triple-entry bookkeeping. [Double-entry](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Double-entry_bookkeeping) bookkeeping was invented in medieval Italy: two parties to a transaction would both record it, giving you more data about your business and more verifiable figures, making it easier to trade and pursue enterprise.

Eight centuries later, distributed ledgers are triple-entry bookkeeping: as well as the seller and buyer, *every participant in the economy* makes a record of the transaction, and every participant is using the same, enormous, book. Blockchain is the technology of how you add to this book and run software with it, and cryptocurrency is one use case: the ledger essentially records how much currency you own, which everyone verifies. Obviously Iâ€™m simplifying, but Iâ€™ll refer to these technologies as â€˜web3 techsâ€™[11](#footnote-11).

The significance of blockchain becomes clear upon interrogating why Facebook, YouTube, *et al.* can take such high take rates on creators. One side is [discovery](https://www.newyorker.com/culture/infinite-scroll/what-the-creator-economy-promises-and-what-it-actually-does#:\~:text=no%20one%20finds%20a%20person%20on%20patreon%3B%20you%20go%20there%20after%20you%E2%80%99ve%20found%20them): you rarely *find* creators on Patreon. This happens, still, on big social networks. Everyone is on these platforms (well, not Facebook) and when you consume on these platforms frequently, theyâ€™re experts in figuring out what content youâ€™ll click on next; big data, [Markov chains](https://towardsdatascience.com/introduction-to-markov-chains-50da3645a50d#:\~:text=predict%20weather%20for%20days%20to%20come%2C%20based%20on%20what%20the%20current%20weather%20state%20is%20at%20the%20time), etc. There are some problems with this, mainly that you get served addictive content rather than niches that you want to engage deeply in, but generally they do this job pretty well, and web3 techs donâ€™t hugely change this.

But there are a lot of platforms for discovery â€” this isnâ€™t the competitive moat it once was. People use Instagram, Snapchat, TikTok, Pinterest, and much more, in addition to the discovery platforms weâ€™ve called out above; as mentioned, most people have moved beyond Facebook. Creators could just move to whichever discovery network takes the smallest cut of their revenue. Apart from one thing: they canâ€™t. Everything youâ€™ve ever uploaded to Spotify and all the followers youâ€™ve earnt on Insta: the discovery platform manages this, and you canâ€™t take your community with you. So itâ€™s impossible to leave without starting all over again. And hence discovery networks [squeeze](https://stratechery.com/2015/niches-problem-subscription-services/) creators for revenue.

And hence, the game-changer. Because just like with your cryptocurrency, you can store your [writing](https://mirror.xyz/), your [music](https://sound.xyz/), your [art](https://opensea.io/), your [videos](https://d.tube/), your [followers](https://lens.xyz/), on a distributed ledger, or â€œon chainâ€. As [LBRY](https://lbry.io/) puts it: â€œLBRY does to publishing what Bitcoin did to money.â€ Just like with your currency, everyone participating in the economy agrees that â€œyes, [Leo](https://app.ens.domains/name/leosn.eth/details), you wrote this blogâ€. Sites like Spotify and Instagram donâ€™t manage your songs and your followers because these songs and follower relationships are stored on chain, and Spotify is reduced to one of many organisations competing to merely display this content in the best way, and help you discover new content as well. Creators are not beholden to any of them â€“ and neither are consumers[12](#footnote-12).

So now the community economy is fully on the way because finally, **dedicated participants in a niche community can meaningfully support their creators**. When people are deeply engaged in something they care about, even the original consumers become contributors, and weâ€™ll start to see vibrant ecosystems formed around niches and creators. Greg Isenberg explores the [Loot ecosystem](https://latecheckout.substack.com/p/heres-what-the-future-of-nfts-looks?s=r#:\~:text=it%E2%80%99s%20an%20ecosystem%20not%20just%20an%20nft), an NFT project upon which creators have realised myriad different ideas; [Jenkins the Valet](https://www.jenkinsthevalet.com/how-it-works) is a great example of community-led storytelling, which will become a category-defining cultural genre in the 2020s, on par with â€˜artâ€™ and â€˜literatureâ€™. [Jadyn Violet](https://twitter.com/jadynviolet), a musician, told me that â€œIâ€™ve never got this much interaction on my art before.â€ He's been spending his time building new ideas to engage his community, spending time speaking with his fans, and making more music â€” this is what his fans love him for.

Business people often talk about the Minimum Viable Product your business needs before you start selling. The MVP isnâ€™t dead, but all businesses (not just creators) will soon require a [Minimum Viable Community](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=_uPRruLfZoU&t=2s) to make a mark in their market[13](#footnote-13).

What will underlie all of these communities are tokens of membership, probably tiered, which tie a community together. Theyâ€™ll be non-fungible, which means theyâ€™ll be unique and personalisable, thus allowing for deeper engagement. **Consumers get dedicated community and deeper value in a niche they care about; creators are finally rewarded fairly for their work.** 

![Tiered NFT collections can help creators build more intimate communities. Everyone wants this; web3 makes it possible. (Peter Yang)](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/OjR9B7mzwKA76xALqr8qk.png?height=512&width=1167)

## An exciting future, not an Exciting one

In 1999, Excite was a $6.7bn search engine, but collapsed soon after the 2001 dotcom crash. Google was only just getting started, but after aligning with the niche market vibe shift of the 21st century, became the favoured search engine of billions.

Joe Kraus, the founder of Excite, [explains why](https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/magazine-23990211#:\~:text=i%20went%20to%20revisit%20joe%20kraus): Excite had been a 20th century company, targeting revenue from the top ten American companies, as media businesses had been doing for decades. Meanwhile, Google focused on attracting advertisers â€” and millions of them. Why did this work? *â€œThe 20th century was about dozens of markets of millions of consumers. **The 21st century is about millions of markets of dozens of consumers.**â€*


---

*Hopefully that didnâ€™t actually feel like 3,000 words; Iâ€™d love it if you were to [subscribe](https://empoweredbelonging.substack.com/subscribe) for free or mint one of 5 editions.*


---

`Image credits: HelloDorking; Kevin Huynh; Peter Yang`

***Footnotes:***

*Mirror doesnâ€™t do footnote links well yet, but I couldnâ€™t bear to publish without them.*

[1](#footnote-anchor-1) I donâ€™t have the percentage figures for the change in sweetshops and clothing stores, Iâ€™m sorry.

[2](#footnote-anchor-2) Other blogging platforms are available, including this one, but theyâ€™re still *built* for writers; Iâ€™m testing the beta of [Nuance](http://nuance.xyz/).

[3](#footnote-anchor-3) Stratechery anticipated this for (cable) TV in [2013](https://stratechery.com/2013/the-jobs-tv-does/#:\~:text=the%20jobs%20tv%20has%20traditionally%20done%20include) and watched it happen in [2017](https://stratechery.com/2017/the-great-unbundling/#:\~:text=tv%20is%20broken%20up%20into%20the%20different%20%E2%80%9Cjobs%E2%80%9D%20it%20has%20traditionally%20done): TV used to keep us **informed**, **educate** us, show **live events**, tell **stories**, and provide **escapism**. But now we get our information from Google; our education from YouTube, Coursera, or Masterworks; our live events from Twitch; our story-telling from Netflix; and our escapism from social media. Itâ€™s not as neat as this of course: in reality, everything just exploded into a plethora of mainly mobile options; but unbundling is happening.

[4](#footnote-anchor-4) I number crunched some of the Instagram follower stats [here](https://mention.com/en/reports/instagram/followers/) and would estimate that of all the follower-followee relationships, the largest 1% of accounts receive about 50% of all following relationships.

[5](#footnote-anchor-5) Iâ€™m undecided and unclear on what this means for â€˜greatâ€™ or â€˜classicâ€™ cultural contributions. If a great cultural contribution captures an image of society, but also moves it on, how can it be classic, if being classic is continuing to capture that image of society: hasnâ€™t society moved on and been influenced by your contribution? 

[6](#footnote-anchor-6) Woodbury is mainly making the argument that it is specifically â€œa 20th-century culture centered around white leading menâ€ that is dying, but whilst itâ€™s true that celebrities are becoming more diverse, whatâ€™s more important is that theyâ€™re becoming less relevant. The social media era is dying; the social community era is coming.

[7](#footnote-anchor-7) Itâ€™s ironic that in principle â€˜agencyâ€™ is the most important thing in the world, whilst â€˜agenciesâ€™ that help brands and creators reach their fans are typically seen as vultures.

[8](#footnote-anchor-8) I also expect niche and tailored content that is ***emphatically artificial***: a further implication of this, from the unrelated and sufficient cause of AI too, is that individuals will asymptote towards consuming cultural content that is tailored just for them: *an audience of one*. As artificial intelligence (which was also covered [last month](http://The asymptote we reach is that for most people, most of the time, their reading and viewing material is created just for them)) gets more able to accurately predict our interests and preferences at a subtle scale, we get to a world in which content is designed â€“ no, generated â€“ to appeal specifically to us. GPT-3 is an OpenAI algorithm that can conduct incredibly lifelike conversation (at times). [The Next Web](https://thenextweb.com/news/openai-punished-dev-used-gpt-3-to-resurrect-dead-ethics) covers the story of one developer who used the algorithm to sell bots that spoke with the *individual personalities* of an individual chosen by a customer, including dead relatives. As always, there are challenges that accompany change, as well as opportunities; AI will continue to develop, but the risk and threat of AI trained to stimulate and manipulate us need to be managed. *Further reading: [The Diff](https://www.thediff.co/p/what-happens-when-most-media-is-produced?s=r) explores this idea from a more financial perspective; the [NPR](https://www.npr.org/2022/03/27/1088140809/fake-linkedin-profiles) illustrates a perfect example, with fake LinkedIn profiles generated explicitly to pique your interest; [Tyler Cowen](https://marginalrevolution.com/marginalrevolution/2022/04/when-your-bot-is-better-than-you.html) touches on the issue from the other perspective, that of the person using the bot.*

[9](#footnote-anchor-9) Sources: Facebook, Instagram, and YouTube stats [here](https://www.forbes.com/sites/marisadellatto/2022/03/24/spotify-says-it-paid-7-billion-in-royalties-in-2021-amid-claims-of-low-pay-from-artists/); in 2021 Spotify paid [$7bn](https://www.forbes.com/sites/marisadellatto/2022/03/24/spotify-says-it-paid-7-billion-in-royalties-in-2021-amid-claims-of-low-pay-from-artists/) to [8 million](https://www.forbes.com/sites/marisadellatto/2022/03/24/spotify-says-it-paid-7-billion-in-royalties-in-2021-amid-claims-of-low-pay-from-artists/) creators, which is $875 or Â£700 (slightly higher than the claim in the a16z source above).

[10](#footnote-anchor-10) Take the price of Bitcoin as a proxy for â€˜web3 in vogueâ€™ for a moment. When a16z published the 100 True Fans articles in February 2020, Bitcoin was worth under <$10k, and wouldnâ€™t get above that price until October. The niche market vibe shift predates the cultural significance of web3 and crypto.

[11](#footnote-anchor-11) Iâ€™m simplifying a lot; this isnâ€™t a technical introduction to web3. Most obviously, itâ€™s not the case that each person has to manually agree everything in a distributed ledger. Rather, itâ€™s every computer server; and itâ€™s not every computer server, itâ€™s those who proactively commit to contributing to manage the ledger and communicating with it. A good introductory podcast [here](https://open.spotify.com/episode/6N7cIUkh0DnADrJpWlzcY3?si=7rj7ns-AQTqwShJvTHRfOQ); a more detailed introduction [here](https://ethereum.org/en/web3/); a more technical and key whitepaper [here](https://ethereum.org/en/whitepaper/); and for more depth I suggest the further reading listed under the whitepaper.

[12](#footnote-anchor-12) This illustrates Vitalik Buterinâ€™s (founder of Ethereum) infamous Uber [quote](https://proxet.com/blog/how-the-blockchain-is-changing-money-and-business/#:\~:text=%E2%80%9C-,whereas%20,-most%20%20tend%20%20workers): taxi profiles will be stored on chain, and Uber, Lyft, and more will compete to show you the same drivers, giving the drivers much more power and compensation â€” which they [need](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Power_resource_theory). *(There we go, I actually got a politics link in.)*

[13](#footnote-anchor-13) This idea comes from Alexis Ohanian, co-founder of Reddit. I donâ€™t think MVC will *replace* MVP - you still need a good product - but your community has to be part of the same conversation.

title: Will P2E NFTs evolve into overpriced loot boxes?
body:
## Long story short, yes, or rather maybeâ€¦

Yes I know that is as vague as it can be, but letâ€™s try to untangle the non-existing regulation around NFTs and what some recent development in European legislation could mean to the emerging market of NFTs.

We need to consider two things:

* Are pre-reveal PFP and P2E NFTs loot boxes?
* If yes, would the loot box legislation apply to them?

### So can we consider NFTs as loot boxes?

We can and we should.

> Loot boxes are a feature within video games that allow players to partake in a game of chance, exchanging real world money for a randomised in-game item or benefit.

In this definition our pre-reveal NFTs could be considered randomized in-game items, especially if they are part of a P2E game, given their attributes are randomly generated from legendary 1/1s to uncommon 10000/1s, which would also constitute a game of chance aspect. Can we say that we can exchange these P2E NFTs for real-world money? Of course, even if the P2E game uses a niche crypto token to purchase these NFTs, we still can exchange our tokens for cash on any CEX and vice-versa.

### So would the loot box apply to the NFT market?

Probably would change how we reveal NFTs, but the market as a whole wonâ€™t be regulated anytime soon.

The most recent addition to the not-so-long list of loot box-related regulations comes as consumer groups in 18 European countries jointly announced that they will launch a coordinated call to action to pass regulations on the despicable practices around loot boxes. The 59=page long report details key issues with loot boxes and their mechanism, a few for the sake of understanding the issue:

* Exploiting cognitive biases and vulnerabilities through deceptive design
* Using aggressive marketing practices to push sales at every opportunity
* Using layers of virtual currencies to mask or distort real-world monetary costs

Even before the years of the pandemic-induced chaos around the world, legislators tried to look into the issue at hand, most notably in Belgium where EA had to stop selling FIFA points, and in the Netherlands, the company was fined 500,000â‚¬ each week they continued selling loot boxes in their games (this decision has been since ruled as unjustified). Following the BENELUX success, the UK government also started a multi-year investigation on whether they could change the gambling legislation to regulate loot boxes accordingly. This was recently published as an overview by the House of Commons Library;

* In September 2019, a House of Commons Committee published a report on technologies that called for regulations to be made to extend the 2005 Act to loot boxes.
* In June 2020, the Government announced that it would be launching a call for evidence into the impact of loot boxes on gambling-like behavior.
* A July 2020 House of Lords Committee report on gambling harm also called for loot boxes to be brought within the scope of the Act.
* On 19 May 2022, the Government said a gambling white paper would be published in the â€œcoming weeksâ€.

If we look at these common issues with loot box mechanisms in the video games industry we can see why they would apply to the current P2E market. Imagine a virtual world where you earn or buy virtual tokens that you can exchange for in-game characters or features, this would be per definition the loot box mechanism that the legislators are trying to regulate to keep children safe. In this regards the general PFP market might also fall into this category.

### What can we do about it?

While the legislators are working on actually taking care of this problem that is now part of most video games, the NFT market should self-regulate and try to come up with a better solution for pre-reveal PFP NFTs and purchasable P2E NFTs.

Do I have a solution? No.

Do I believe in NFT technology? Yes.

title: HASH DAO ($HASH) Whitepaper
body:
*Updated : May 2022*

**Mission : Our mission is to cultivate Web3 community horticulture for the future of the cannabis space.** 

HASH DAO provides the first unified DAO solution forÂ craft cannabis farmers, industry professionals, investors, and BIPOCÂ communitiesÂ interested in theÂ cannabis space.

HASHÂ DAO has been created to allow integration into the emerging technologies of the blockchain and Web3 into the cannabis space. Focusing on farmers who put the plant first and under represented communities. To do this, we start by partnering with Uncle Mac's brand to create the worldâ€™s first Web3 Cannabis brand and community tooling of horticulture. Building a growing compilation of automation protocols using smart contracts, HASH DAOÂ Governance seeks to be the future industry standard.

**Problem : Removing the Gatekeepers to Funding Craft Cannabis Operators**

*â€œDecades of marijuana prohibition and high incarceration rates for marijuana convictions has left many people out of the legal marijuana boom.â€*

> **Barriers of Entry + (Profit > People) = Current State of the Cannabis Space**

The multi-billion dollar cannabis industry is entering itâ€™s boom phase as more global cannabis markets arise and support for [U.S. federal legalization](https://www.congress.gov/bill/117th-congress/house-bill/3617) continues to grow support, in 2020 alone the cannabis space grew to over $20 Billion and is projected to 10x in the next decade.

Malpractice and gatekeeping of the cannabis industry has traditionally maximized profits at the cost of the plant or people, and in turn have provided barriers to entry to craft cannabis farmers and the BIPOC community.

Corporate cannabis companies operate and control the majority of the space, leaving legacy operators and small brands without capital solutions to scale their businesses and do not take into consideration all of itâ€™s stakeholders :

* The Growers & Phenotype Hunters
* Cannabis Processing & Technology
* Dispensaries & Deliveries
* Consumers & Community
* Mother Earth

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/oXXVXLuIXOQoXtXRqzBXV.png?height=621&width=904)

The majority of the craft cannabis space, lacks in metrics and does not reward innovation or intellectual property; often operating at the cost of the patient, plant and the planet.

Cancerous pesticides, mold, and in-organic genetically modified flowers have all been out-dated practices utilized in current cannabis horticulture. This is largely due to a profit-driven model of the medicinal plant which has unjustly fined small legacy growers. Incarceration of marginalized communities for alternative medicine use at a disproportionate rate has since gate-kept entry into the space.

Farming, hash-processing, and cannabis tech are often driven to innovation by financial corporate investors, many times leaving most of the developers, designers, and legacy growers at the short end of the intellectual property stick. Elite genetics are identified by farmers through years of R/D sorting through phenotypes of each strain. Many times big brands exploit years of hard work and value that passionate master growers put in and often donâ€™t receive proper credit. Certain strains go on to become cultural identities that generate massive value, I.E. the creators and farmers innovate and the investors profit off their intellectual property, currently there is no on-chain authentication process.

Although track-and-trace is currently implemented, most cannabis brands are not completely transparent with their grow methods and techniques of production. There is also massive risk for current cannabis businesses as they have become targets for robberies the past few years. Legal brands are facing counterfeits and knock-offs in the black market. With the integration of digital identities, NFTs/Web3 purchasing, and automation, many of these problems are easily solved.

**HIGHLIGHT FRESH FROZEN PROBLEM**

![Exclusive Libraries of Genetics & Phenos](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/-8T4OrLTcNOJxW2vLerl-.jpg?height=1866&width=1536)

*Solution?* Highly Autonomous Systems of Horticulture (**$HASH**) : Utilizing smart contracts to automate and democratize production, supply chain, and governance in the cannabis & psychedelic industry.

Creating community-ownership of the vertically-integrated $HASH Supply Chain of production, processing, distributing, and operating on-chain craft cannabis  compliance geared toward Web3 adoption. Information, data security, and their applications are essential for business optimization and transparency. Although there are many ERP solutions for the industry already, our governance will be centered around cannabis supply chain and DeFi dApps that utilize NFT-based SKUâ€™s to generate active product data and create on-chain interactions that comply with ESG metrics, paving the way for global regulations and the future of the cannabis space.

Developing Horticulture Public Goods : BIPOC Horticulture Initiative, Open-Source Library of Genetics, Strains and Phenos, Regenerative Farming Methods & Techniques, Cannabis Production, Processing, Entheogenic Cultivation, Medicinal Protocols, and a Community-Practitioner Directory

Community-Governance over the liquidity, yield-farming, and major-user decisions in the tokenization of HASH DAO. 

**DERO Data Privacy** **+ Tokenization of Security**

HASH DAO Governance is the future of the industry standard, and to do this we will start by partnering with one successful Emerald Triangle, Northern California craft cannabis-brand with community-staking of its future scaling of operations and expanding a compilation of automation protocols through smart contracts.

**ON-CHAIN SUPPLY NFTs + ACTIVE INVENTORY TRACKING + CRYPTO TRANSACTIONS = Web3 Point of Sale (PoS)**

**Worldâ€™s First Cannabis DAO Founded On**:

BIPOC-equity and engineered around community-development governed by craft cannabis operators, backed by IRL projects.

**On-Chain Protocols + Smart Contracts = The Automated Horticulture of Tomorrow**

Creating a future:

* Geared to the love and cultivation of the plant and Mother Earth
* Onboarding BIPOC leaders and creatives onto the blockchain
* Compensating intellectual property proportionally to fulfill smart contracts

> **HASH DAO = Power Back in Your Hands**

Reinvention of the Horticulture Supply Chain and Data Distribution via smart contracts that allow for automation and help individuals to create ownership over community-led projects, intellectual property, digital assets, and dApps.

![](https://images.mirror-media.xyz/publication-images/M6C2p0sNHx37p783TEv9D.jpg?height=822&width=1125)

**First Wins for HASH DAO**

> â€œCommunity Ownership of Physical and Digital Assetsâ€

Minting a multi-tiered HASH DAO NFT with the top governance tier going for $10 K, raising a total of $11.5 M for an initial $HASH treasury. As funds become available, proceeds will immediately go to partnering with South Face Mangement to purchase over 30 acres in Mendocino and 40+ acres Humbolt County. This will include the scaling of a vertically-integrated nursery, farm, hash processing, and soon-to-launch retail of award-winning legacy products under Uncle Macâ€™s brand and South Face Farms Management.

**Project #1 :**  Carry out renovation on the farm and nursery to ensure full-scale ESG-metric compliance and how to bring all aspects of the farm and itâ€™s production on-chain, from SKU NFTâ€™s to utilizing energy consumption data for carbon credit checks. Partnering with Uncle Macâ€™s, a Northern California craft cannabis brand, & South Face Management, parent company to Flower Wheel Nursery, South Face Farms Cultivation, and Uncle Macâ€™s brand.

**Project #2 :** Onboard visual and 3D artists who will design branding and assets for the Metaverse and we develop cross-chain NFTâ€™s to be dropped on various play-to-earn games. We will also be acquiring digital plots of real estate to build â€œMetaverse farmsâ€ and â€œdigital dispensariesâ€ where a user can view the product, find out all of itâ€™s information, and have it eventually delivered through an on-chain transaction. Along with digital land we will also be investing in domain names, including various strain names, cannabis celebrities, and psychedelic culture. Explore liquidity pools and yield farming with assets and treasury.

**Project #3 :** For the third project, weâ€™ll be launching Uncle Mac's HASH House is an Emerald Triangle legacy project. This on-chain Hash House is the home lab for Uncle Macâ€™s production. We will also operate as a wholesale fresh frozen supply chain solution for transportation, storage, distribution and hash toll processing throughout the greater Emerald Triangle area.

**Project #4** : Getting $HASH in your hands. This is our farm-to-table craft cannabis buyers club providing direct-to-consumer access to exclusive SKUâ€™s from legacy brands in the Emerald Triangle. This will include obtaining a retail and event license to launch Nephewâ€™s Automated.

**Project #5 :** Aggregating a library of horticulture public goods & building the Biodiversity BIPOC Glamping Learning Initiative; start building Marijuana for Minorities ProgramÂ to co-create $HASH University creating content with some of the best small-batch growers and washers in the industry. (Community Online Education)

**Project #6 :** Nephewâ€™s will be applying for its event space license building the foundation for Akasha, an immersive psychedelic A/R Lounge for BIPOC community healing. The distribution and delivery will be a warehouse that will have an on-chain ESG-metric system in the back and a public access immersive art space in the front. We will also be looking into developing a portfolio of boutique cannabis bud and breakfasts in emerging global cannabis markets.

**Project #7 :** We will be finding ERP solutions to develop state-of-the-art horticulture automation and Web3 technologies, based upon on-chain governance and compliance, to pave the way for the international industry standard by working towards meeting ESG-metric compliance. Our final goal is developing complete automation systems without compromising craft horticulture. From driverless deliveries, farm drone surveillance & data collection to utilize machine-learning and AI and to understand buyer behavior, horticulture improvements, growth optimization, etc.

title: Will P2E NFTs evolve into overpriced loot boxes?
body:
## Long story short, yes, or rather maybeâ€¦

Yes I know that is as vague as it can be, but letâ€™s try to untangle the non-existing regulation around NFTs and what some recent development in European legislation could mean to the emerging market of NFTs.

We need to consider two things:

* Are pre-reveal PFP and P2E NFTs loot boxes?
* If yes, would the loot box legislation apply to them?

### So can we consider NFTs as loot boxes?

We can and we should.

> Loot boxes are a feature within video games that allow players to partake in a game of chance, exchanging real world money for a randomised in-game item or benefit.

In this definition our pre-reveal NFTs could be considered randomized in-game items, especially if they are part of a P2E game, given their attributes are randomly generated from legendary 1/1s to uncommon 10000/1s, which would also constitute a game of chance aspect. Can we say that we can exchange these P2E NFTs for real-world money? Of course, even if the P2E game uses a niche crypto token to purchase these NFTs, we still can exchange our tokens for cash on any CEX and vice-versa.

### So would the loot box apply to the NFT market?

Probably would change how we reveal NFTs, but the market as a whole wonâ€™t be regulated anytime soon.

The most recent addition to the not-so-long list of loot box-related regulations comes as consumer groups in 18 European countries jointly announced that they will launch a coordinated call to action to pass regulations on the despicable practices around loot boxes. The 59=page long report details key issues with loot boxes and their mechanism, a few for the sake of understanding the issue:

* Exploiting cognitive biases and vulnerabilities through deceptive design
* Using aggressive marketing practices to push sales at every opportunity
* Using layers of virtual currencies to mask or distort real-world monetary costs

Even before the years of the pandemic-induced chaos around the world, legislators tried to look into the issue at hand, most notably in Belgium where EA had to stop selling FIFA points, and in the Netherlands, the company was fined 500,000â‚¬ each week they continued selling loot boxes in their games (this decision has been since ruled as unjustified). Following the BENELUX success, the UK government also started a multi-year investigation on whether they could change the gambling legislation to regulate loot boxes accordingly. This was recently published as an overview by the House of Commons Library;

* In September 2019, a House of Commons Committee published a report on technologies that called for regulations to be made to extend the 2005 Act to loot boxes.
* In June 2020, the Government announced that it would be launching a call for evidence into the impact of loot boxes on gambling-like behavior.
* A July 2020 House of Lords Committee report on gambling harm also called for loot boxes to be brought within the scope of the Act.
* On 19 May 2022, the Government said a gambling white paper would be published in the â€œcoming weeksâ€.

If we look at these common issues with loot box mechanisms in the video games industry we can see why they would apply to the current P2E market. Imagine a virtual world where you earn or buy virtual tokens that you can exchange for in-game characters or features, this would be per definition the loot box mechanism that the legislators are trying to regulate to keep children safe. In this regards the general PFP market might also fall into this category.

### What can we do about it?

While the legislators are working on actually taking care of this problem that is now part of most video games, the NFT market should self-regulate and try to come up with a better solution for pre-reveal PFP NFTs and purchasable P2E NFTs.

Do I have a solution? No.

Do I believe in NFT technology? Yes.

> P.S.: Sorry for making this article an NFT, just wanted to try this functionality out.

title: THE FOOLISHNESS OF PRIDE: AN ESSAY ON CANCEL CULTURE
body:
What do you think of when I say the words â€˜Cancel Cultureâ€™?

Youâ€™ll feel some kind of way about it. Youâ€™ll either posit that it doesnâ€™t exist (that the cultural practice of â€˜cancellingâ€™ is a form of accountability and consequences for bad behavior), that it does exist but isnâ€™t that big of a deal, or that it is a huge cultural problem. At any rate, you have a neuronal pattern that lights up inside of your brain when you process the english word pairing â€˜cancelâ€™ and â€˜cultureâ€™ in immediate succession. Let me extend that for you.

Whether or not â€˜cancel cultureâ€™ exists does not change the fact that a pattern of consciousness has entered our awareness and we are attempting to name it. We donâ€™t necessarily have clean lines and clear boundaries around what this thing *is*, but enough of us have bumped up against it in some capacity that thereâ€™s a collective â€˜senseâ€™ that something new is here. Thereâ€™s some kind of force at work in people, for any number of reasons. Maybe itâ€™s the way that social media incentives are designed; maybe itâ€™s the way that our modes of production have systematically disempowered the vast majority of participants in â€˜the marketâ€™ and made us feel like collective vitriol is our only recourse in moments of injustice; maybe itâ€™s a general lack of emotional and intellectual maturity in the average user â€“ myself included â€“ leading us to quickly shout unkind hyperbole in the wake of â€˜the latest dramaâ€™. Itâ€™s probably all of these things, but itâ€™s also something deeper and more insidious than that.

Cancel Culture is an *Egregore*. Strap in.

The word *[egregore ](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Egregore)*refers to an esoteric concept that was introduced to me by the astrologer [Fairlie Theta](https://thatastrologer.medium.com/). She explained it to mean â€œan emergent force created and existing through the intellect of large groups of individualsâ€. Itâ€™s like a creature â€“ some kind of semi-divine entity whose body is not physical, but rather, psychological. It exists via distributed thought patterns; it is the embodiment of a meme. While you canâ€™t see it with your eyes, you could if you had some kind of x-ray vision and could pull your focus back a few miles; itâ€™s body is literally the thought patterns that exist in many peoplesâ€™ minds simultaneously. Our physical bodies become its cellular loco-motors, our vocal cords and fingertips become its viral vectors, and it does its work on society by hijacking our social incentives and changing our behavior patterns to suit its proliferation.

It may be useful to define *[meme](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Meme)* here as well; in an academic sense, memes (and their accompanying field of research known as *mimetics*) describe self-replicating information that spreads through human communication. The atheist and evolutionary biologist Richard Dawkins coined the term to deliberately mirror the concept of genes and genetics; whereas genes are bits of *physical* information that self-replicate (through biochemistry), memes are *psychological* or *intellectual* bits of information that self-replicate. When we share a silly video online and suddenly it spirals out into remixes and new interpretations, we are watching the process of mimetic evolution take place in real time. In certain contexts, memes can become totally untethered from their inciting â€˜thoughtâ€™, and can distort existing social incentives to become world-shaping forces of good and evil. Religion is a meme; democracy, too. Memes are a useful tool for understanding the anthropological relationships we all experience in a global society. The concept of the Egregore is a bit like personifying a specific meme-pattern. You take a meme, and you imbue it with being, as though it has a primal intelligence all its own.

*Itâ€™s my opinion that, by imbuing an otherwise abstract but observable pattern such as â€˜cancel cultureâ€™ with a primal intelligence, we become better able to think of ways to productively relate to the concept.* We as individuals only have agency to address something like â€˜cancel cultureâ€™ in so far as we are able to understand it as a process that operates under its own logic and desire to persist. Ergo, Egregore.

â€œThe Egregore of Cancel Cultureâ€ is a bit of a mouthful, though. Letâ€™s condense that to its essence: What human emotion is most at work when we talk about Cancel Culture? What pattern of consciousness does this phenomenon most exalt?

Maybe there really is no such thing as â€˜cancel cultureâ€™; maybe weâ€™re talking about the material incarnation of *Pride*. The great sin made manifest in the flesh â€“ a bonafide adversary.

At the core of the idea of â€˜cancellingâ€™ (wherein a human being who is perceived by a contingent of society to have done something harmful, abusive, or immoral, becomes the target of a focused campaign of harassment in an effort to inflict psychological or physical harm on the person as a form of retribution) is fueled on almost every level by *shame*. The â€˜cancellersâ€™ are wielding shame to try and destroy the mental well-being and social reputation of a perceived target; the target will likely invoke shame towards the cancellers in an effort to protect themselves and their reputation. At the same time, both cancellers and target are (unconsciously) wielding *pride* to justify their position in the dynamic. Pride, after all, is the polarity of shame; these energies produce each other in proportion to their intensity. When we project shame onto others, we do so in part because it makes us feel like we are morally superior to the target of that shame. We play the part of canceller because it makes us feel like we are better than they are and therefore that we have something to be proud of, and we play the part of cancelled for the same reason. How many people now use the fact that they have been cancelled as a branding technique? How many people are twisted into the upside down logic of shame, entirely unaware of how their actions are in service of the extraperceptual superentity known as Pride?

[Eckhart Tolle](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Eckhart_Tolle) addresses this phenomenon through the language of the hungry ego. In his work, â€˜[A New Earth](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/A_New_Earth)â€™, he discusses the way in which our sense of self is habitually conflated with our identity: we forget that *we are not* our name, our history, our memories or our context, but are rather something transcending all of that which has no beginning or end because it is pure â€˜awakenessâ€™, pure consciousness. We forget this, because our egos are hungry, and the ego eats by telling itself a story about who and what it is. It was Tolleâ€™s work that made me realize even in moments of self-pity and suicidal depression, the ego is feasting and strengthening itself. We sometimes talk about the ego as though it is only present in those who think highly of themselves, but Tolleâ€™s point seems to be that the ego doesnâ€™t care whether you think of yourself in a positive or negative way â€“ it cares that you think of yourself *at all*, that you think of yourself as *being real*. Your ego can feast voraciously on the idea that you are a bad person deserving of exile, just as surely as it can feast on the notion that you are a good person capable of determining who else is deserving of exile. Egos grow fat on the unconscious and automatic narratives that emerge from drama, conflict, and argument. Egos *crave* conflict; itâ€™s somewhere between a buffet and a day trip to the gymnasium for them. If you spend all of your time embroiled in arguments on the internet about the right politics, you are constantly reinforcing and training your ego.

And what is the egoâ€™s most desired delicacy?

Pride, and Shame. Which are one and the same.

Our medium of communication â€“ that is, *[social media](https://www.thecenterforsophiologicalstudies.com/post/persona-ideology-the-egregore-and-social-media)*, whose incentives are not spiritual or political but economic â€“ has been designed to exploit this phenomenon for monetary gain. These platforms are fueled by advertising, and by the creation of â€œ*engagement*â€, coming from compelling â€œcontentâ€. They are agnostic as to the nature of the content, and are happy to encourage whatever social phenomenon is the most compulsive. As it turns out, the feeding of our egos is extraordinarily effective at this. The whole machine is built like a video game for ego competition. You have a score. You have a player character. You have feedback and gameplay loops. You have metrics for comparing your performance to everyone else who is playing. When you score a â€˜hitâ€™ you are rewarded with dings and bells and little red lights and numeric indicators of how effectively you have â€˜dunkedâ€™ on the other team. Unconsciously, whether you are winning or losing, your ego is *constantly* being bombarded with affirmations. You are loved and cherished, you are unimportant, you are hated, you are respected, you are *known*. *You are real*.

There is no incentive within the system for large numbers of humans to gain a deeper understanding of how this game works, or to become self-aware about the ways in which we engage in it. On the contrary: the system works best when we are completely incurious about our modes of engagement and allow the algorithm to unscrupulously guide us towards certain topics, certain products, certain kinds of emotional reaction, etcetera. When the phenomenon of a â€˜cancellationâ€™ begins, the algorithm detects human engagement and pours gasoline onto the fire, making everyone in everyoneâ€™s network simultaneously aware of the opportunity to dive in and be a part of the game. Get it while itâ€™s hot, get those clever dehumanizing meta-ironic comments out there now while itâ€™s trending, because your sense of self-worth is now inextricably connected to how many likes you get on that tweet. If you hesitate, you lose points, and if you canâ€™t get that delicious serotonin, how are you going to get out of bed in the morning? What is the point, in this nihilistic capitalist hellscape?

The proclivity for mass shaming has always been present in the human species, but its nature and cumulative effect has radically transformed along with our technological development. If you set aside your moral judgments and get curious about the intimate psychological process of â€˜cancellingâ€™ as it occurs within a single individual, youâ€™ll see an ancient pattern that once served the vitality of the tribe. If you were a band of hunter-gatherers smaller than [Dunbarâ€™s number](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dunbar's_number) (150 people or less) and someone in that tribe was accused of some foul transgression, getting the group together to collectively shame the culprit had a good likelihood of producing the desired effect: behavioral change, or true exile of the bad actor. This process served the long term survival of the group; itâ€™s where our impulse to collectively shame *comes from*.

But, as with our wisdom teeth, evolution is not a perfect process. Internal combustion and circuit boards progress much faster than the biological reality of the human animal does. Our impulses and mental models are squishy and slow whereas our communication networks are now lightning quick, and when you introduce the same bundle of animals into environments with wildly different rules, you get wildly different outcomes. Collective shaming *does not work* in a globally interconnected society of diverse perspectives. We do not have a community of Dunbarâ€™s number â€“ we have communities of *hundreds of millions* *or billions*, all connected through the same server farms, all one IP address away. If you identify a morally deficient agent in the world and you bring your evolutionary tendency for mass shaming to bear on them, how easy it now is for that individual to put out an alarm signal and find themselves brought into and protected by a rival faction who thinks that, actually, *you* are the morally deficient one. The more we give in to that shaming impulse, the more polarized these two perspectives become; the more intense and fierce you become with your campaign to destroy or exile this other person, the more fuel you give to the parallel narrative that you are the ones deserving of punishment, and ironically, the more status you give to your target within their parallel community. The harder and louder and more intensely you attempt to cancel that person â€“ unless they are found convincingly guilty of universally detested behavior, as in the case of someone like Harvey Weinstein â€“ the more power you lend to that person as they splinter away from you. Nothing has changed in the animal behavior; but the technology that augments it has changed the way that equation unfolds.

So much of these fascinating and chaotic processes are the direct result of our childish relationship with our newfound technological potency. These technologies have had less than a lifetime to mature, and weâ€™ve all had to learn how to use them from the ground up. The conflict and violence present at all levels of our society today is the natural result of handing a bunch of children the tools to wage a global psychic and spiritual war against one another. Meanwhile, the egregores that feast upon our patterns have never been stronger.

Perhaps my desire to contextualize different problems in the world as these emergent eldritch beings is a foolâ€™s errand. Maybe it really doesnâ€™t matter how we think about these things, and maybe projecting this concept of â€˜the adversaryâ€™ onto these forces wonâ€™t affect how people choose to relate to or engage with them. In my heart I find inspiration in the idea that I am waging war against dark angels who care not for the beauty and complexity of an individual human soul. It helps me remember that my enemy is not the person engaging in the destructive behavior, but the destructive behavior itself. It helps me consider how and why that pattern of consciousness is able to become so entrenched, and it helps me think about it not in terms of changing other peoplesâ€™ brains but in terms of what this monstrous being eats, and how to deprive it of that food. We evolved to create â€˜the otherâ€™ â€“ some kind of being outside of our tribe that we can rally against â€“ as a form of protection, and in a global society where we are regularly challenged to understand the whole of humanity as our tribe, I think we may still need â€˜the otherâ€™. The egregore of Pride feasts upon our shame, and we feed it constantly, unconscious to what we are doing. We default to shaming one another because weâ€™ve inherited these ancient evolutionary patterns and have yet to realize how our indulgences do not serve us, our stated goals, or the well being of our now global tribe. We default to scorn and dismissal because weâ€™re exhausted by the pattern of our lives and it makes dumb animals of us all. We justify our refusal to change these maladaptive processes because we hold pride and shame around them; the idea that we need to change them would require us to grapple with the very uncomfortable notion that *the world is this way because of us*. There is a massive shame looming in our unconscious, held back by the dam weâ€™ve constructed out of pride that tells us, â€œNo, it cannot be our responsibility, we have identified the culprit and it is *them*.â€

I think now of the phenomenal quote by the psychedelic shaman Terrence McKenna:

> â€œNature loves courage. You make the commitment and nature will respond to that commitment by removing impossible obstacles. Dream the impossible dream and the world will not grind you under, it will lift you up. This is the trick. This is what all these teachers and philosophers who really counted, who really touched the alchemical gold, this is what they understood. This is the shamanic dance in the waterfall. This is how magic is done. By hurling yourself into the abyss and discovering it's a feather bed.â€

The real antidote to shame is not Pride; itâ€™s *courage*. Courage to confront your own inadequacies. Courage to take responsibility for the state of the world. Courage to recognize moments of conflict not as a *them* problem, but rather as your own communication deficiencies. You are missing something, you have not gained the necessary wisdom, you lack compassion or empathy and these are the real reasons you have been unable to have productive discourse. Yes, the systems select against it, yes, social media is designed to foster these communication breakdowns, yes, other people have their parts to play and you cannot be *their* absolution (nor should you allow them to force it upon you), but as a sovereign citizen of this universe, spending any amount of time or energy concerned with *other peoplesâ€™* *paths* is a waste of your power. Your path and your actions are what you have power over. There is a looming fear of worthlessness inside of you in direct proportion to how much you project that energy onto others. If you are constantly identifying the moral deficiencies in other human beings, that is the biggest, brightest red flag that somewhere within you, you fear the same deficiency in yourself. Your fear â€“ that is, your lack of courage â€“ may prevent you from looking at this truth in the face, but it is where these conflict patterns come from. If you ever want to heal that wound, you *have* *to have courage*.

This is the message of the Fool and the Fox, the core principle that brings [the mission of Anthromancer](https://anthromancer.com/pages/about) into focus. To be a Fool is to think of yourself as enlightened as the Fox; but to be a Fox is to recognize that you will always be a Fool, and to embrace that truth with courage and humility. There is nothing to be afraid of; we are all sinners, we are all imperfect unfolding processes within the perfect fabric of creation. Our past transgressions and the deep vitriol weâ€™ve held for those we perceive as committing wicked deeds of their own, like all forces in nature, change over time. They are not static and eternal judgments against a personâ€™s very soul. They are moments that we experience in the grip of truth, and then move through, as the truth itself transforms around us. This is the nature of all things, yet we treat ourselves and others as though momentary judgments become the de-facto rule of a personâ€™s eternal totality. This is, as the buddha would say, wrong thinking, and the whole world begins to heal when we correct such wrong thinking inside our own minds.

As I revise this essay I find it interesting I should feel compelled to write it at the beginning of Pride month. Pride â€“ the festival of liberation from shame that was created in the wake of the 1969 Stonewall Riots as lesbian, gay and transgender people from all backgrounds stood up for their right to exist as they were without shame â€“ is really a movement of *courage*. It makes sense that people who had lived under the constant oppressive force of shame for something inherent to their identity would create a movement named after what is seen as the opposite of that oppressive force. And itâ€™s not really my place to tell anyone how they should posture and what label they should use. But in its most divine incarnation, the lessons the rest of the world can learn from the queer community have nothing to do with â€œprideâ€, and everything to do with courage â€“ the courage to face the imposition of shame and remain unmoved by it. The courage to accept that some people will want you to die simply for existing in your natural state, and to choose not to allow that fear to prevent you from chasing that authenticity. The courage to stand up in the face of psychological and physical acts of violence, knowing that you may suffer obliteration. Itâ€™s about courage.

Reactionary religious voices will look at the aesthetics â€“ that is, the label of â€œprideâ€ â€“ and quake in their boots at what they perceive to be the most depraved distortion of deadly sin into holy virtue, and warn their children against it, and disown members of their own family, and fracture the human tribe in the wake of their own hidden shame, more concerned with keeping up appearances in their community and â€˜the eyes of Godâ€™ than in deep reflection and curious investigation into the real patterns that govern all of these processes. They, too, are gripped by the tendrils of Pride. They forget themselves and they forget the lessons of their own scripture; they fall into patterns of fear and perceive them as patterns of love, seemingly unaware of what faith really means, and how bulletproof true faith in Godâ€™s love ought to make you feel. They subsume their power into ideologues and political charlatans and make the same kinds of cancel culture justifications for casting their own flesh and blood out into the world, and lack the courage to inquire into their own reasons for doing this...because the egregore of pride and shame has totally colonized the minds of *everyone* in our society.

In this sense, I find the LGBTQ communityâ€™s generational attempts to exist in public without shame to be one of the more divine manifestations of love in the world. Here is a group of people who are casting off the shame that society imposes on them in its pride. Here is a group of people who are trying, perhaps imperfectly at times, to make a world that is more kind and more accepting of different ways of being, so long as those ways of being do not harm others. Perhaps they are all prideful fools...but so are we all. It isnâ€™t something we chose. It is something we inherited, and it is our responsibility to become aware of that pattern and to choose something different. That starts with how we choose to relate to one another. It starts with how we choose to relate to ourselves. And more than anything, it starts with courage; the courage to love ourselves and to love those who hate us, to love our imperfections and the imperfections of others, and to understand what a gift we are giving ourselves in doing so.

I believe this is what Jesus of Nazareth was trying to teach the world when he died trying to absolve us of our sins; the point is that your sins do not condemn you. We are all sinners, we are not alone, and we have nothing to be afraid of. It is what it is, and you are still worthy of love. It does not matter who you are, where youâ€™ve been, or what youâ€™ve done, and it does not matter what other people say or think about you; the love we are talking about is the most radical love imaginable. Itâ€™s love beyond measure. Itâ€™s infinite, and eternal, and itâ€™s always one tuning of your consciousness away; itâ€™s always there for you, once youâ€™ve got the tools you need to access it. It doesnâ€™t matter what language you speak, what holy book you read, or if you even believe that God is real. The love weâ€™re talking about doesnâ€™t care about any of these superficial cosmic hashtags. It cares about one thing, and one thing only:

Courage.

How wicked do we become when we operate from a place of fear? How twisted do our values get when we filter them through the axis of pride and shame? How useless is our creative agency when we lose sight of what we actually want, and fail to build logical frameworks for how to achieve those goals, because weâ€™re torqued up in a maelstrom of low-vibrational animal reactivity?

Do you want to build a better world? You cannot do it alone. You cannot exile and shame your way towards a more enlightened humanity. You cannot genocide the undesirables, no matter what your criteria for what â€˜undesirableâ€™ means. You have to deepen your love and lift people up, not with weakness, but with strength; not with suspicion, but with faith; not with fear, but with courage. Our hollow institutions arenâ€™t going to suddenly become enlightened until we kill the egregores that own them. Thatâ€™s a battle that starts right here, right now, in you.

How do you want to do this?
